Alexander Grothendieck 10 selected works: Alexandre Grothendieck's work profoundly influenced algebraic geometry and related fields, with many of his papers forming the backbone of modern mathematical concepts. Here is a list of 10 significant papers and publications that represent his groundbreaking contributions: 1. "Sur quelques points d'algèbre homologique" (Tohoku Paper): This foundational paper, published in the Tohoku Mathematical Journal in 1957, introduced key concepts in homological algebra, such as abelian categories and derived functors, which are fundamental to modern mathematics. 2. "Éléments de géométrie algébrique" (EGA): This multi-volume series, co-authored with Jean Dieudonné, established a rigorous framework for algebraic geometry, introducing the concept of schemes and laying a foundation for future studies in the field. 3. "Séminaire de géométrie algébrique" (SGA): A series of seminar notes compiled from Grothendieck's lectures, covering a range of topics in algebraic geometry. Notable sub-volumes include SGA 1 (revised fundamental group) and SGA 4 (étale cohomology). 4. "Théorie des topos et cohomologie étale des schémas" (SGA 4): This volume introduced the concept of topos, a significant extension of the concept of a topological space, and laid the groundwork for étale cohomology. 5. "Cohomologie locale des faisceaux cohérents et théorèmes de Lefschetz locaux et globaux" (SGA 2): This paper extended classical results and introduced key ideas in local cohomology, with implications for Lefschetz theorems. 6. "Faisceaux algébriques cohérents" (FAC): This paper was a precursor to EGA, establishing many fundamental concepts in the study of coherent sheaves in algebraic geometry. 7. "Le théorème de dualité pour les faisceaux algébriques cohérents" (Grothendieck Duality)**: This work on Grothendieck duality provided a deep understanding of duality in algebraic geometry, extending classical duality theories. 8. "Motifs: la motivic cohomology": Grothendieck's idea of motives, explored in various papers and seminars, aimed to unify different cohomology theories, with profound implications for algebraic geometry. 9. "Le théorème de Riemann-Roch": This paper extended the classical Riemann-Roch theorem, introducing new concepts and setting the stage for further developments in algebraic geometry. 10. "Topos theory and categorical methods": This paper or collection of papers introduced new categorical methods in algebraic geometry, broadening the conceptual framework for subsequent research. These papers capture some of Grothendieck's most important contributions to mathematics and his innovative approach to problem-solving in algebraic geometry and related fields. Sun-Yung Alice Chang (Chinese: 張聖容 ) (1948) is a Taiwanese American mathematician specializing in aspects of mathematical analysis ranging from harmonic analysis and partial differential equations to differential geometry. She is the Eugene Higgins Professor of Mathematics at Princeton University. Here are some key highlights of her scientific contributions: 1. Conformal Geometry: Chang has made significant contributions to conformal geometry, an area of mathematics focusing on properties that remain unchanged under conformal mappings. Her work in this field has helped deepen the understanding of how geometric structures behave under these transformations. 2. Geometric Inequalities: She has worked extensively on geometric inequalities, which are fundamental in understanding the relationships between different geometric quantities such as volume, area, and length in various geometric contexts. Her research has led to advancements in the comprehension of these inequalities in curved spaces. 3. Yamabe Problem: Chang has made notable contributions to the Yamabe problem, a famous problem in differential geometry concerning the existence of a metric with constant scalar curvature in a given conformal class on a compact manifold. Her work in this area has been influential in advancing both the theoretical understanding and practical applications of this problem. 4. Harmonic Analysis on Non-Compact Symmetric Spaces: Her research also extends to harmonic analysis, particularly on non-compact symmetric spaces. This work involves studying functions and their transformations and has applications in many areas of mathematics and theoretical physics. 5. Einstein Metrics and the Ricci Flow: Chang's work has contributed to the study of Einstein metrics and the Ricci flow, important concepts in differential geometry and general relativity. Her research in this area helps in understanding the geometric and topological properties of manifolds. 6. Analysis of Partial Differential Equations: She has also made significant contributions to the analysis of partial differential equations, which are fundamental in expressing a wide range of physical phenomena. Her work has implications in understanding complex systems in mathematical physics. 7. Mentorship and Leadership in Mathematics: Beyond her research, Chang has been a mentor and leader in the mathematical community. She has served in various significant roles, including as the President of the Association for Women in Mathematics, promoting diversity and inclusion in the field. Sun-Yung Alice Chang's work is characterized by its depth and its impact on both pure and applied mathematics. Her contributions have not only advanced theoretical knowledge but have also had practical implications in understanding the complex geometrical and analytical structures of the natural world. https://lnkd.in/dBbXQiWu AIFI - Artificial Intelligence Finance Institute

Vladimir Igorevich Arnold ( 1937 – 2010 ) was a Russian mathematician. He is known for the Kolmogorov–Arnold–Moser theorem regarding the stability of integrable systems, and contributed to several areas, including geometrical theory of dynamical systems theory, algebra, catastrophe theory, topology, algebraic geometry, symplectic geometry, symplectic topology, differential equations, classical mechanics, differential geometric approach to hydrodynamics, geometric analysis and singularity theory, including posing the ADE classification problem. Here are some of his key contributions: 1. KAM Theory: Together with Andrei Kolmogorov and Jürgen Moser, Arnold developed the Kolmogorov-Arnold-Moser (KAM) theory. This theory addresses the stability of integrable systems in classical mechanics and provides conditions under which an integrable Hamiltonian system can be slightly perturbed without becoming chaotic, thus explaining the persistence of quasi-periodic motions in certain systems. 2. Arnold Diffusion: In celestial mechanics, Arnold contributed to the understanding of the diffusion process in the phase space of Hamiltonian systems, which can lead to slow changes in the orbit of a celestial body over a long time. 3. Singularity Theory: Arnold made significant advancements in singularity theory, which studies the properties of spaces that are not smooth, like the points of a cone or the edge of a cube. His work laid the foundation for understanding the classification and characterization of singularities in different contexts. 4. Arnold's Conjecture in Symplectic Geometry: This conjecture relates fixed points of a Hamiltonian symplectomorphism to the topology of the underlying manifold. It has been a central problem in symplectic geometry and has driven much research in the field. 5. Topological Fluid Dynamics: Arnold applied topological methods to the study of fluid dynamics, offering a new perspective on the behavior of incompressible flows. This approach led to what is now known as Arnold's structure theorem, which describes the global structure of steady flows. 6. Arnold's Cat Map: In the field of dynamical systems, Arnold introduced the concept of the cat map, a linear, chaotic map that is an example of an Anosov diffeomorphism. This concept is used in various fields, including cryptography and image processing. 7. Ergodic Theory: Arnold also made contributions to ergodic theory, which deals with the statistical properties of dynamical systems. 8. Mathematical Education: Beyond his direct research contributions, Arnold was known for his unique approach to teaching. His textbooks and problems have influenced mathematical education worldwide. Arnold's work is characterized by its depth, originality, and the elegant application of geometric and topological methods to solve complex problems in various fields of mathematics and physics. Stephen Smale ( 1930 ) is an American mathematician. He has made many significant scientific contributions throughout his career, primarily in topology, differential equations, and dynamical systems. Smale was awarded a Fields Medal at the International Congress in Moscow in 1966. Here's a deeper look into some of his major contributions: 1. Horseshoe Map: In the realm of dynamical systems, Smale introduced the concept of the "horseshoe map," which became a foundational example of chaotic dynamics. The Smale horseshoe is a mechanism that helps explain the generation and persistence of chaos in deterministic dynamical systems. 2. Higher-dimensional Poincaré Conjecture: Smale resolved the general Poincaré conjecture for dimensions greater than or equal to 5 in the early 1960s. This was a monumental achievement in the field of topology. 3. Differential Topology: Smale also produced a list of fundamental problems in the area of differential topology. His work led to the development of the "h-cobordism theorem," which implies that high-dimensional smooth manifold structures are classified by their homotopy types. 4. Singularities of Smooth Maps: Smale delved deep into the classification and characterization of singularities in smooth maps. He provided a classification for stable singularities in differentiable mappings. 5. Structural Stability: In the study of dynamical systems, Smale investigated the question of which systems are structurally stable. This deals with understanding which systems remain topologically conjugate under small perturbations. 6. Global Analysis: Smale made essential contributions to global analysis, especially in understanding the behavior of dynamical systems in broad settings, beyond the scope of traditional differential equations. 7. Computation and Complexity: Later in his career, Smale became interested in the computational aspects of various problems. He explored questions related to the complexity of algorithms and the challenges associated with solving polynomial equations. 8. Economic Equilibrium: Venturing outside traditional mathematics, Smale has made contributions to the theory of economic equilibrium, specifically relating to the existence and computation of equilibria in economic systems. 9. Mathematical Biolog: Smale's interests also extended to mathematical biology, particularly in the areas of learning and the neurosciences. https://lnkd.in/drwAm8Jp Throughout his career, Stephen Smale has showcased an exceptional ability to traverse and contribute to a variety of mathematical fields. His work has not only deepened our understanding of complex mathematical structures and phenomena but has also forged links between seemingly disparate areas of study. Robert Phelan Langlands, ( 1936 ) is a Canadian mathematician. He is best known as the founder of the Langlands program, a vast web of conjectures and results connecting representation theory and automorphic forms to the study of Galois groups in number theory,for which he received the 2018 Abel Prize. He also got the Wolf Prize in 1995. He was an emeritus professor and occupied Albert Einstein's office at the Institute for Advanced Study in Princeton, until 2020 when he retired. Here are some key aspects of his scientific contributions: 1. Langlands Program: Langlands' most significant contribution is the formulation of the Langlands program. This set of conjectures and ideas, first proposed in a letter to André Weil in 1967, seeks to create a grand unifying theory linking areas of number theory, representation theory, and algebraic geometry. The program suggests deep connections between Galois groups (which arise in the study of polynomial equations and their roots) and automorphic forms (complex-valued functions with certain invariance properties). 2. Reciprocity Conjectures: A cornerstone of the Langlands program is the series of reciprocity conjectures. These conjectures generalize class field theory (which describes abelian extensions of number fields) to non-abelian Galois groups, proposing a correspondence between Galois representations and automorphic representations. This was a revolutionary idea that opened up new ways of thinking about and studying these mathematical objects. 3. Functoriality and Endoscopy: Langlands introduced the concept of functoriality within his program, which deals with how automorphic representations of one group relate to those of another group. He also developed the theory of endoscopy, a set of techniques to understand the internal structure of automorphic representations, particularly in cases where functorial transfer is not straightforward. 4. Trace Formula: Langlands made significant contributions to the development of the trace formula, a powerful tool in the study of automorphic forms. The trace formula is an analytic tool that allows mathematicians to count automorphic representations with certain properties. 5. Influence on Other Fields: The Langlands program has influenced various other areas of mathematics. It has played a role in the proof of major theorems, such as the proof of Fermat's Last Theorem by Andrew Wiles, and has been instrumental in the development of the theory of Shimura varieties in algebraic geometry. 6. Collaborations and Mentoring: Beyond his own research, Langlands has been influential through collaborations and mentoring other mathematicians, contributing to the growth and development of the field. His contributions have not only opened new avenues of research but have also provided a framework that connects various seemingly disparate areas of mathematics. https://lnkd.in/d7BYmRP4 AIFI - Artificial Intelligence Finance Institute

Pierre René, Viscount Deligne ( 1944 ) is a Belgian mathematician. He is best known for work on the Weil conjectures, leading to a complete proof in 1973. Has made significant contributions to several areas of mathematics, especially in algebraic geometry and number theory. He is the winner of the 2013 Abel Prize, 2008 Wolf Prize, 1988 Crafoord Prize, and 1978 Fields Medal. From 1970 until 1984, Deligne was a permanent member of the IHÉS staff. In 1984, Deligne moved to the Institute for Advanced Study in Princeton. His most notable achievements include: 1. Proof of the Weil Conjectures: Deligne's work on the Weil conjectures is perhaps his most celebrated contribution. These conjectures, proposed by André Weil, relate the number of solutions of equations over finite fields to the topology of the equations' complex solutions. Deligne's proof of the last and deepest of these conjectures, the "Weil conjecture on Tamagawa numbers," earned him the Fields Medal in 1978. 2. Deligne Cohomology: In algebraic geometry, Deligne developed a theory of mixed Hodge structures and introduced what is now known as Deligne cohomology. This work has had a profound impact on the field, providing deep insights into the nature of algebraic varieties. 3. Work on Hodge Theory and Singularities: Deligne made significant contributions to Hodge theory, which is a central tool in modern algebraic geometry. His work helped in understanding the role of singularities in various contexts, which has applications in many areas of mathematics. 4. Contributions to the Langlands Program: He has also made important contributions to the Langlands program, a set of deep conjectures connecting number theory and representation theory. 5. Tannakian Categories: Deligne's work on Tannakian categories has been influential in representation theory and algebraic geometry. This concept provides a framework for understanding linear algebraic groups and their representations. 6. Kazhdan–Lusztig Conjectures: Deligne, along with David Kazhdan and George Lusztig, worked on the Kazhdan–Lusztig conjectures, which have deep implications in representation theory and algebraic geometry. 7. Moduli Spaces and Stacks: He has done significant work in the study of moduli spaces and stacks, which are important in the study of algebraic surfaces and other geometric structures. Deligne's work, characterized by deep insight and technical mastery, has had a wide-ranging impact across mathematics, influencing both the development of new theories and the solution of long-standing problems. https://lnkd.in/daEpuZGF Sources: Wiki, Yves Laszlo, Raphael Douady, IAS, IAs and Humans AIFI - Artificial Intelligence Finance Institute

Peter Scholze 1987 is a German mathematician known for his work in arithmetic algebraic geometry. He has been a professor at the University of Bonn since 2012 and director at the Max Planck Institute for Mathematics since 2018. He has been called one of the leading mathematicians in the world. He won the Fields Medal in 2018. These are some of his most remarkable contributions: 1. Perfectoid Spaces: - Scholze's development of perfectoid spaces has been a major breakthrough in arithmetic algebraic geometry, providing a unifying framework to study the arithmetic of different number fields. 2. Advances in the Langlands Program: - His work has significantly advanced the Langlands program, particularly in understanding the connections between number theory, geometry, and representation theory. 3. p-adic Hodge Theory: - Scholze, along with Laurent Fargues, has been pioneering a new approach to p-adic Hodge theory, which is expected to have profound implications for the geometric Langlands program. 4. Tilting Correspondence: - The tilting correspondence discovered by Scholze is a fundamental principle that allows for the comparison of geometric structures over complex and p-adic fields. 5. Condensed Mathematics: - Together with Dustin Clausen, Scholze is developing the framework of condensed mathematics, which aims to refine the foundations of topology and geometry to better suit modern mathematical needs, especially in the context of p-adic analysis. 6. Liquid Tensor Experiment: - Scholze has initiated the Liquid Tensor Experiment, challenging the mathematical community to formalize a part of his work in analytic geometry using a proof assistant, which is a significant step towards the computer-aided formalization of complex mathematical theories. 7. Awards and Recognition: - His numerous awards, including the Fields Medal, underscore the impact of his deep contributions to mathematics. Peter Scholze's work is characterized by its originality, depth, and the broad implications it has for the field of mathematics. His contributions continue to influence a wide range of mathematical disciplines, and his ongoing research is closely watched by the mathematical community for further groundbreaking results. https://lnkd.in/ddwbxK_T AIFI - Artificial Intelligence Finance Institute

Carl Gustav Jacob Jacobi ( 1804 – 1851 ) was a German mathematician who made fundamental contributions to elliptic functions, dynamics, differential equations, determinants, and number theory. Some of his key contributions are: 1. Elliptic Functions: Jacobi made substantial contributions to the theory of elliptic functions. He developed the theory of elliptic functions based on the inversion of elliptic integrals and introduced the Jacobi elliptic functions, which became fundamental in complex analysis and number theory. 2. Jacobi's Theta Function: He introduced the theta function, which plays an important role in number theory and has applications in physics, especially in string theory and soliton theory. 3. Jacobi Identity: In the field of algebra, the Jacobi identity is an important property of the commutator in Lie algebras and has applications in various areas of physics. 4. Hamilton-Jacobi-Bellman Equation: Jacobi's work, in conjunction with that of William Rowan Hamilton and later extension by Richard Bellman, contributed to the formulation of the Hamilton-Jacobi-Bellman (HJB) equation. This equation is a cornerstone in optimal control theory, providing a method to determine the optimal control law for a given system. The HJB equation is fundamental in dynamic programming and finds applications in various fields, including economics, finance, and robotics. The equation is a type of partial differential equation and is instrumental in solving complex optimization problems in dynamic systems. 5. Jacobi Symbol: In number theory, the Jacobi symbol is a generalization of the Legendre symbol to all odd numbers, and it's essential in computational number theory. 6. Jacobi's Algorithm for Determining Eigenvalues and Eigenvectors: In numerical linear algebra, Jacobi's algorithm is a method for determining the eigenvalues and eigenvectors of a real symmetric matrix. 7. The Jacobian matrix consists of first-order partial derivatives of a vector-valued function, mapping changes in input to changes in output. It's a crucial tool in calculus and optimization for understanding system behavior, performing linear approximations, and solving equations. 8. Jacobi Triple Product: In the theory of q-series, the Jacobi triple product is a fundamental identity that expresses an infinite product as an infinite sum. 9. Contributions to Differential Equations: Jacobi made several contributions to the theory of partial differential equations and their applications. 10. Jacobi's Last Multiplier: A concept in the theory of differential equations that provides a systematic method for finding integrating factors. 11. Jacobi Integral: A key concept in the dynamics of rotating bodies. Jacobi's work was characterized by its depth and its unifying approach to mathematics, influencing various areas of the field. Fermat's last theorem is easy to be explained to any high school student. Pythagorean triples (x,y,z) of integers satisfy x^2 + y^2 = z^2. To avoid trivialities, one stipulates none of x,y,z is zero. This is what we term as Fermat's theorem for n = 2. The n = 3 generalization asks the question: can we find three integers x,y and z satisfying x^3 + y^3 = z^3. It is taught in a university level number theory class that this n = 3 case would work only when one of x, y or z is zero. The most general version for an arbitrary positive integer n is precisely the theorem known as FLT (Fermat's last theorem) (Fact: no nontrivial solutions exist, we do need one of x,y or z to be zero). In his death bed, Fermat made a note in his diary stating this theorem and claiming "I do have a proof of this but this margin is too narrow to jot it down". Mathematicians spent centuries trying to prove until Wiles did so about four decades ago. People believe Fermat did not really have a proof (or if he had one, it would have been incorrect). So much higher math and new math disciplines had to be developed just to prove this theorem. When Wiles announced his proof, we (as PhD students) had to learn the idea of proof. It was too hard and too long - even the outline of proof (top level steps) requires three hours of lecturing. I did lecture on this outline in many universities across the globe (first one being at University of Malaysia), mostly for undergraduate students with sufficient exposure to Mathematics.
